If $H$ is bipartite with minimum degree $r$ then there exists $\epsilon=\epsilon(H)>0$ such that\[\mathrm{ex}(n;H) \gg n^{2-\frac{1}{r-1}+\epsilon}.\]



Conjectured by Erd\H{o}s and Simonovits \cite{ErSi84}. A probabilistic argument shows that there exists some $\epsilon=\epsilon(H)>0$ such that\[\mathrm{ex}(n;H) \gg n^{2-\frac{2}{r}+\epsilon}.\]This conjecture was disproved by Janzer \cite{Ja23} for even $r\geq 4$. The case $r=3$ was disproved by Janzer \cite{Ja23b}, who constructed, for any $\epsilon>0$, a $3$-regular bipartite graph $H$ such that\[\mathrm{ex}(n;H)\ll n^{\frac{4}{3}+\epsilon}.\]In \cite{Ja23} Janzer conjectures that the above lower bound is sharp, in that for any $r\geq 3$ and $\epsilon>0$ there exists an $r$-regular graph $H$ such that\[\mathrm{ex}(n;H) \ll n^{2-\frac{2}{r}+\epsilon}.\]Janzer's result proves this for even $r\geq 4$.

See also [113], [146], and [714].

See also the entry in the graphs problem collection.
